Feasting on the vermilion dawn, jade mushrooms fill and overflow.
Halting the kalpas’ years, decayed bones return to youth.
Longevity of heaven and earth, eternally enjoying without end.
Body born of water and fire, transforming by the hundreds of thousands."*

When finished, guide the vermilion qi and swallow it three times, then ingest the twelve Vermilion Writ jade characters of the south.

These twelve characters are the names of the Three Qi Cinnabar Heaven. They guide the Three Qi of the Vermilion Thearch and ingest the Vermilion Sprout, all written in vermilion on white paper, visualized and then swallowed whole. Thus, the vermilion qi is guided to flow and overflow with fragrant mushrooms, pouring into the crimson palace. The Vermilion Thearch descends in truth to the visualization, receiving the vermilion writ from the numinous youths, preserving the Vermilion Sprout to endure forever, ingesting the Three Qi of Zhu Rong. The vermilion jade tablet flourishes to communicate with the numinous, revolving the Five Chapters to summon the spirits. Through long fasting and silent resonance in the Great Stillness, one’s name is inscribed in heaven above the southern window. Truly, this is effortlessly attained without difficulty, eternally enjoyed without end.

Always, at cock’s crow when the yang light first divides, face south, click the teeth three times, rub the hands until warm, and with the palms wipe the face and eyes three times. Raise the gaze and pray:

*"Southern Vermilion Cinnabar, ingesting the Vermilion Cinnabar,
drinking from the Cinnabar Pool."*

When finished, with the tongue lick the lower teeth and the sweet lips, rinsing the mouth until the jade mushrooms fill it, and swallow three times.

Then draw in the vermilion *qi* and swallow it three times, allowing it to settle within the Heart Palace. Thus the Dao is complete.

**The Primordial Vermilion Script: Ingesting and Guiding the Central *Qi* of Wu-Ji—The Jade Formula of the Yellow Heaven**

To cultivate the Yellow Sprout, guide the twelve *qi* of Wu-Ji, and align with the Central Yellow Heaven. Always at cock’s crow on the spring equinox, summer solstice, autumn equinox, and winter solstice, enter the chamber, face the sovereign, and bow twelve times. Sit upright, click the teeth twelve times, and visualize the Central Jade Treasure, the Primordial Numinous Elder Lord—surnamed Tongban, named Yuanshi, styled Han Shuniu. His form stands one foot and two inches tall, crowned with a yellow essence jade coronet, clad in five-colored feathered robes, riding a yellow dragon jade chariot, bearing a yellow banner. Twelve myriad attendants of the Wu-Ji Yue Lao officials descend from the twelve *qi* of the Yellow Heaven into the chamber. Soon, yellow *qi* transforms and surges forth, radiant as luminous clouds, enveloping one’s form and entering through the mouth to descend directly into the Spleen Palace. Then visualize the Earth Star blazing in the central sky, its light illuminating the body. Hold the vision clearly, then open the eyes and pray:

*"Central Yellow Mount Tai, the Primordial *Qi* lingers.
Above dwells the Primordial Elder, governing the Four Peaks.
Riding the yellow dragon, clad in five-colored feathered robes,
Guiding the Nine Heavens, revolving the celestial pivot.
The Earth Star blazes bright, scattering radiant light.
Jade blossoms and fragrant mushrooms fill the four directions.
They bathe my form, the Spleen Palace unfurls fresh.
Nurturing the sprout, ingesting essence, the myriad spirits converge.
Restraining the hun and po, refining the Eight Potencies,
Within and without, all becomes luminously clear, ever-living without decline.
Communing with the real, attaining the numinous, ascending into the Great Tenuity."*

When finished, draw in the yellow *qi* and swallow it twelve times. Cease. Then ingest the sixteen characters of the Central Vermilion Script’s jade text. These sixteen characters are the names of the Central Yellow Heaven. To guide the twelve *qi* of the Yellow Emperor and ingest the Yellow Sprout, write them in vermilion script on white paper, visualize them, and swallow them whole. Thus the Primordial *Qi* is drawn down from the Nine Heavens, and the Mystic Throat pours into the Wondrous Gate. The Granary of Heaven fills without grain, the Spleen Palace glows without kindling. The Elder responds in harmonious resonance, the Numinous Youth opens his robes to receive the script. The White Prime moves swiftly to command the east and west. Wondrous indeed is this jade formula, the origin of the myriad immortals.

Always at cock’s crow when the yang light first divides, face the sovereign, click the teeth twelve times, rub the hands until warm, and with the palms wipe the face and eyes twelve times. Raise the gaze and pray:

*"Central Wu-Ji, majestic Mount Tai,
Ingesting essence and *qi*, drinking from the sweet spring."*

When finished, with the tongue stroke the upper palate and the Mystic Throat, gather the Jade Spring, lick the lips three times, and swallow. Then draw in the yellow *qi* twelve times, allowing it to settle within the Spleen Palace. Thus the Dao is complete.

**The Primordial Vermilion Script: Ingesting and Guiding the White Sprout of the Seven *Qi*—The Jade Formula of the White Heaven**

To cultivate the White Sprout and guide the seven *qi* of the White Heaven. Always at cock’s crow on the day of the autumnal equinox, enter the chamber, face west, and bow seven times. Sit upright, click the teeth seven times, and visualize the Western Seven Treasures Golden Gate, the Radiant Numinous August Elder Lord—surnamed Shangjin, named Changkai, styled Yao Po Bao. His form stands seven inches tall, crowned with a white essence jade coronet, clad in white feathered flying robes, riding a white dragon, bearing a purple banner. Seventy myriad attendants of the Geng-Xin Xuan Lao officials descend from the seven *qi* of the White Heaven into the chamber. Soon, white *qi* transforms and billows forth, vast as autumn clouds veiling the sky, enveloping one’s form and entering through the mouth to descend directly into the Lung Palace. Then visualize the Metal Star blazing in the west, its light illuminating the body. Hold the vision clearly, then open the eyes and pray:

*"Golden Numinous Seven Gates, resplendent in the Western Flower.
Within dwells the White August One, the Primordial’s abode.
Riding the white dragon, the seven *qi* towering,
Lingering at the Jade Gate, scattering crimson radiance.
The Metal Star emits its glow, fragrant mushrooms flourish.
They bathe my form in mystery, nurturing my White Sprout.
The Bright Stone shines with fresh light, enduring through ten thousand kalpas.
Drinking from the flowing spring, ingesting the Great Harmony,
The Nine Heavens’ Lord bestows jade blossoms.
Preserving years, halting whiteness, the countenance blooms with splendor.
Abiding long with heaven and earth, the Three Luminaries share eternity."*

When finished, draw in the white *qi* and swallow it seven times. Cease. Then ingest the twelve characters of the Western Vermilion Script’s jade text. These twelve characters are the names of the Western Seven *Qi* White Heaven. To guide the seven *qi* of the White Emperor and ingest the White Sprout, write them in white script on white paper, visualize them, and swallow them whole. The deities of the Seven *Qi* Heaven pour forth the mysterious white radiance to irrigate, the Bright Stone naturally grows, and jade mushrooms flourish. The Lung Palace opens luminously to receive the real, the Granary of Heaven glows without sustenance. The White Numinous responds in resonance, driving and commanding, riding through the gates of the Nine Heavens. Cultivating without cease, one’s lifespan equals that of the Primordial.

Always at cock’s crow when the yang light first divides, face west, click the teeth six times, rub the hands until warm, and with the palms wipe the face and eyes seven times. Raise the gaze and pray:

*"Western Bright Stone, ingesting the Bright Stone,
Drinking from the numinous liquid."*

When finished, with the tongue stroke the upper teeth, lick the lips, rinse the mouth until jade mushrooms fill it, and swallow three times. Then draw in the white *qi* seven times, allowing it to settle within the Lung Palace. Thus the Dao is complete.

**The Primordial Vermilion Script: Ingesting and Guiding the Mysterious Sprout of the Five *Qi*—The Jade Formula of the Dark Heaven**

To cultivate the Mysterious Sprout and guide the five *qi* of the Dark Heaven. Always at cock’s crow on the day of the winter solstice, enter the chamber, face north, and bow five times. Sit upright, click the teeth five times, and visualize the Northern Cavernous Yin, the Solitary Absolute, the Five Numinous Mysterious Elder Lord—surnamed Heijie, named Linghui, styled Yin Houju. His form stands five inches tall, crowned with a dark essence jade coronet, clad in dark feathered flying robes, riding a black dragon jade chariot, bearing a black banner. Fifty myriad attendants of the Ren-Gui Qiang Lao officials descend from the five *qi* of the Dark Heaven into the chamber.

In an instant, black *qi* is transformed and generated, its radiance layered and shimmering, its light as dazzling as a shooting star. It envelops one’s form, enters through the mouth, and descends straight into the Kidney Palace. Then visualize the Water Star gleaming brightly in the north, its light illuminating one’s body, all bathed in brilliance.

Thereupon, open the eyes and raise the gaze in prayer, saying:
*"Northern Dark Heaven, five *qi* disperse numinous power.
Above dwells the Great Spirit, the Primordial Elder of Original Essence.
Riding dragons and bearing banners, they roam the Upper Capital.
This day is supremely auspicious, felicitous clouds spread their glory.
Flying mushrooms scatter like rain, suffusing all four directions.
Jade maidens of the Mysterious Mystery pour over my form.
The Kidney Palace is filled and stabilized, withered sprouts revive anew.
The Five Palaces receive the true, ascending to commune with the divine.
The Five Elders descend to greet, the Dao of immortality swiftly attained.
Transforming water and fire, clad in azure-feathered robes.
Soaring through the Great Void, journeying to the Purple Court.
Lifespan equal to the Three Luminaries, eternal through ten thousand kalpas."*

When finished, guide the black *qi* and swallow it five times, then cease. Next, ingest the twelve characters of the Vermilion Script of the Northern Direction. These twelve characters are the names of the five *qi* of the Northern Dark Heaven. The method of guiding the five *qi* of the Black Emperor and ingesting the Mysterious Sprout is all written in vermilion script upon white paper; after completing the visualization, consume it at once. Thus, the Elder of the Mysterious is registered in the Vermilion Numinous Realm, the numinous youth’s name inscribed upon the Vermilion Script. The five *qi* flow with mushroom essence into the withered abode, jade springs surge in pools at the Central Gate. The spirit stabilizes the numinous marrow, the Kidney Palace generates warmth. The Jade Maidens of the Great Mystery are dispatched east and west, never waning through ten thousand kalpas, the Elder of the Mysterious abiding as one.

Always at cock’s crow, when yang light first divides, face north, click the teeth five times, rub the palms until warm, and wipe the face and eyes five times. Raise the gaze in prayer, saying:
*"Northern Dark Essence, ingest the Dark Essence, drink the Jade Elixir."*

Then, with the tongue, stroke the inner lower teeth, sweetening the lips and rinsing the mouth until Jade Mushrooms fill the mouth; swallow three times. Again, guide the black *qi* into the abdomen, allowing it to stabilize within the Kidney Palace. Thus, the Dao is complete.

Of old, the Dao spoke of the method of guiding and ingesting the sprout: always on the days of the eight solar terms, enter the chamber in purity and fast, visualize the forms of the Five Elders, and after reciting the incantations, guide and ingest the names of the heavens according to each direction. Practicing this for eight years, immortal officials will come to welcome you, jade maidens will attend as guards, and your body will radiate light, illuminating the ten directions. You will roam freely, the Five Emperors bowing in reverence, the Three Realms’ administrators coming to greet. This rank is the title of the Perfected of the Three Heavens.

This text is fully preserved within the Southern Garden’s Vermilion Grotto and Five Cities, guarded by the immortal officials of the Three Heavens. Twelve-tiered immortal towers house it in a coffer of purple jade, inscribed with golden tablets, adorned with cinnabar mushrooms and luminous herbs. It is transmitted alongside the Central Chapter of the Most High, conferred only upon those whose names are inscribed in the immortal registers of the Cinnabar Terrace, destined to become Perfected of the Second Heaven. Without this tally, one shall never attain it. According to the ancient statutes, it emerges once every four hundred years.

At the hour of the cock’s crow, compose the body and settle the spirit, then proceed in order. First ingest the verdant sprouting qi of the Eastern Quarter, then the Southern, then the Central, then the Western, then the Northern—once the Five Emperors’ qi has been received according to the method above, strike the teeth thirty-six times and swallow the qi twenty-five times, then cease.

Then recite the general incantation:
White rocks towering, one after another,
Fountains gushing, like jade nectar.
Drink of this and live forever,
Lifespan extended without end.

Once finished, stir the tongue against the upper and lower palate and center, filling the mouth with jade mushrooms, then swallow three times. Again draw in the qi twenty-five times, swallowing until the qi reaches its utmost, and the Dao is complete.

*The Wondrous Scripture of Limitless Salvation, Great Method of the Upper Scripture, Scroll Nineteen—End*
*The Wondrous Scripture of Limitless Salvation, Great Method of the Upper Scripture, Scroll Twenty: The Hidden Writ and Mysterious Image*

The Mysterious Master said: When Heaven and Earth first opened, the images of the Five Phases and Three Powers all took form and substance. That humans can fully embody the qi of Heaven and Earth yet cannot endure long is because they are open to transformation but cannot restrain their spirit, nurturing the qi of pure truth yet instead becoming prey to demonic and malevolent forces.

If one can cultivate the qi of Heaven, one may attain celestial perfection. If one cultivates the qi of the torch, it transforms into demonic spirits. This is easy to know but difficult to practice, easy to practice but difficult to articulate.

The Dao of long life and ascension is nothing other than attaining the Dao, yet those deluded remain mired in the realm of sensual desire. Though the *Hidden Writ of the Wondrous Treasure* speaks little, its practice is profound. To keep the pure qi from withering amid sensual desire and to clarify the turbid qi within the depths of sinking, one must await the flowing of the kalpa of Red Clarity. Those who study above surpass those below—none can attain it.

When our August Sovereign obtained it, floating in the void, he established images within the utmost essence. The sun, moon, and stellar lodgings, wind and rain, the four seasons—all reside within the upright qi. The *Biographies of the Jade Pivot* revolve day and night. If mortals can preserve the Dao of long life without entering the realm of cyclic rebirth, all is distinguished within the *Hidden Writ*, its chapters clearly delineated. Having glimpsed the gateway to the essential path of long life, one must ascend from the mundane to the sagely with ease.

Those who attain the rank of Upper Immortal thereby comprehend the mysteries of wind, rain, and darkness. Those who attain the rank of Lower Immortal thereby fathom the mechanisms of life and death. Kings and lords who attain it harmonize with the four seasons, nourishing the myriad beings, summoning and sensing the harmonious qi, and thus attain long life.

Ordinary people, unaware of how to entrust their forms, equate themselves with Heaven and Earth, yet dissipate their spirit, qi, and blood, hastening decline and death. The secret of long life in the *Wondrous Treasure* circulates and flows, returning to the root and restoring the mandate. The hun and po chant and sing, the qi and blood suffuse with radiance. Thereafter, one conceals the form and eludes traces, hunger and cold cannot assail, demons and toxins are dispelled, and one withdraws from the world, forsaking its flavors.

As for attaining the Dao of effortless long life—the origin of the myriad methods—it does not lie beyond this threshold. Thus, within the Four Poles of Heaven, the Sanskrit texts of Brahmā’s resplendent sounds comprise one pole of sixty-four characters, which are the written symbols of the Five Phases and hexagrams, inseparable from the human body. If one can awaken to understanding with each breath, merging essence and qi, harmonizing the numinous sounds, one becomes a person of long life and deathlessness.

In Heaven, it forms the sounds and qi of the celestial signs; on Earth, it forms the shapes and substances of the myriad beings; in humans, it is obtained through the subtle interplay of awareness. Thereafter, one knows emptiness as not-empty and form as not-form—this is called illumination, penetrating the wondrous sounds of the self. The body aligns with Heaven and Earth, the qi merges with the *Hidden Writ*.

Those who know the sounds practice seven stages:
First, the body becomes light;
Second, the spirit becomes tranquil;
Third, the qi becomes complete;
Fourth, the essence becomes unobstructed;
Fifth, the spirit transforms;
Sixth, one attains numinous communication;
Seventh, one becomes a treasure.
Naturally harmonized, one ascends to the Upper Clarity, soaring to the Golden Gates and roaming the Jade Capital.

*The Talisman of the Great Demon-Quelling Might of the Azure Emperor*

For all who wish to receive and uphold it: On the day of the Beginning of Spring, with sincere devotion, burn incense and face the first light of the eastern sun. On *jiǎzǐ*, *gēngshēn*, and the Three Origin days, at the hour of the cock’s crow, sit upright, close the eyes, clasp the hands, and remain at ease. Await the qi to settle and become even and harmonious. Do not rub the face or eyes with the hands, lest the spirit and qi be disturbed.

Exhale with saliva to rinse the mouth, swallow the saliva once, and strike the teeth three times. Then draw in a breath of qi, regulating the breath until it is even. Exhale gently through the nose, slowly and evenly, until the qi naturally suffuses the skin, blood vessels, and pores, and the six senses become pure and clear. This cultivates the qi of Non-Arising Life in the Eastern Quarter of Azure Vastness.

Draw in a breath of qi to nurture embryonic breathing. If one does not draw in the qi, it rushes into the Southern Palace of the Heart Emperor, where the mutual overcoming of the Five Phases renders it unusable.

To prolong the breath, focus the mind and eyes on the nostrils, and it will naturally endure. Then hold the breath for a long duration, listening inwardly with the mind as if to the buzzing of flies or insects.

When ordinary people observe and listen to sounds and sights, their spirit scatters and flees through the ears and eyes, leading swiftly to illness, short life, or premature death. By constantly listening inwardly with the mind, as if to the sound of insects, the hun and po remain undispersed. Thus, dwelling in the realm of sensual desire, if one constantly practices this method, passions and desires will naturally fade, the spirit will not decline, and one will not know this method only when the spirit is exhausted and the essence depleted—then death draws near.

Next, visualize the body transforming into mountains, rivers, forests, and trees, as if standing beneath Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon. With prolonged practice, the essence and qi are inwardly preserved, and one perceives the body as a mountain’s image, stabilizing the hundred spirits. Thus, the essence and qi are generated and preserved, and illnesses naturally heal.

At this point, slowly open the eyes and swallow the talisman with pure water—this summons the Azure Emperor to guard the hun. According to the *Hidden Writ of the Eastern Quarter*, from *Dǎnlóu Ācāng* to the Four Images of *Xūyuán*, these are the Eight Heavens of the East, corresponding to the eight trigrams. The aforementioned sixty-four characters divide the sounds and qi into sixty-four hexagrams, belonging to the Wood Virtue of the Spring Office, the flourishing essence of luxuriance.

The Eastern Dipper governs destiny, under the governance of the Azure Emperor. Within the human body, it serves as the Guardian of the *hun*, presiding over the *hun* of the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, hair, and the Gate of Life. The celestial demon of the East is named Bayuan Choubo, subject to the *Tianpeng* military arts. On *wuchen* and *jisi* days, the *nayin* corresponds to Wood. One should practice the Eastern *qi* talisman and concurrently employ the Central Ultimate *qi* talisman. On days when the *nayin* pertains to Wood, follow this method: combine the aforementioned four characters into one talisman, or inscribe them in large or small seal script according to form.

When inscribing this talisman, face east, hold the left palm upward, press the thumb against the middle finger’s center, and grasp the brush with the right hand. Recite the sixty-four characters of the Eastern Eight Heavens’ sound-text, then visualize the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the East suspended in the clouds, midair, lowering a pearl like a pellet. Strike the teeth three times, draw a mouthful of azure *qi* from the pearl, and blow it onto the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"By the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning, Bayuan Choubo, Demon King, receives the Great Law of Tianpeng. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute!"*

Next, inscribe the talisman in cinnabar: first write *Bayuan Choubo*, then trace the eight trigrams atop the characters, layering them. Write the character *chi* (敕), then turn the brush nine times counterclockwise before lifting it.

**Great Demon-Subduing Talisman of the Vermilion Heaven**
Light incense, sit calmly, and regulate the breath for over ten cycles until even and prolonged. Visualize the heart as a lotus flower, then rinse the mouth, swallow the saliva, and moisten the throat. Imagine the *qi* of the heart connecting with the *qi* of the eyes, then direct the heart’s *qi* upward to the crown of the head, passing behind it with a sound like thunder, as if wind and rain, residing between the brows. Envision the pupils of the eyes as twin golden rings. Rotate the golden rings nine times counterclockwise before the eyes.

If one sees flowers—yellow or black—before the eyes, it signifies the dispersion of essence and *qi*, with the spirit-light straying outward, causing ocular ailments. Practicing this Nine Revolutions of Spirit-Light method restores luminosity, preserving clarity even in old age. Next, imagine the body enveloped in fierce flames, feeling a slight warmth. Then visualize the Pillar of Heaven, resounding with thunder and lightning, sensing the opening of every pore and bone, the body bathed in ascending and descending dew—this possesses great power to sever evil and repel malevolence.

According to the *Hidden Writ of the Southern Quarter*, from *Nanyan Dongfu* to *Shenying Zigong*, these are the Eight Heavens of the South, corresponding to the eight trigrams. The sixty-four characters divide the sounds and *qi* into sixty-four hexagrams, belonging to the Fire Virtue of the Summer Office, the radiant essence of brilliance. The Southern Dipper governs life, under the governance of the Vermilion Emperor. Within the human body, it serves as the Nurturer of *Qi*, presiding over the Gate of the Heart Emperor’s generative *qi* and the pivot of vitality.

The celestial demon of the South is named Futian Danshi, subject to the *Tianyou* military arts. On *bingyin* and *dingmao* days, the *nayin* corresponds to Fire. One should practice the Southern *qi* talisman and concurrently employ the Central Ultimate *qi* talisman. On days when the *nayin* pertains to Fire, follow this method.

When inscribing the talisman, face south, press the thumb against the first joint of the middle finger, grasp the brush, and recite the sixty-four characters of the Southern Eight Heavens’ sound-text. Visualize the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the South suspended above the clouds, lowering a jewel like a pellet. Strike the teeth three times, draw a mouthful of vermilion *qi* from the jewel, and blow it onto the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"By the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning, Futian Danshi, Demon King, receives the Great Law of Tianyou. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute!"*

Next, inscribe the talisman in cinnabar: first write *Futian Danshi*, then trace the eight trigrams. Write the character *chi* (敕), turn the brush three times, and lift it as prescribed.

**Great Demon-Subduing Talisman of the White Emperor**
Light incense, sit calmly, face west, and regulate the breath for over ten cycles until even. Visualize a golden light radiating from the heart, illuminating all, then direct the heart’s *qi* into the two breasts. Once accomplished, rinse the mouth, swallow the saliva, and guide it into the Flowery Canopy of the lungs. Imagine the body within a forest of seven treasures, beholding mountains of extraordinary height—towering like ten thousand *ren*—rising from the great sea, concealed from the mundane world.

Next, visualize two *yongquan* (bubbling spring) acupoints beside the breasts. From beneath the Cinnabar Heaven, *qi* ascends into these points, flowing outward and dispersing into the sea—this is the method of counterflow, preserving essence and *qi*. If the *qi* of the two breasts is depleted, the heart’s sound resembles a pestle, influenced by the corpse-spirit.

According to the *Hidden Writ of the Western Quarter*, from *Daoli Chanyou* to *Baikong Duxian*, these are the Eight Heavens of the West, corresponding to the eight trigrams. The sixty-four characters divide the sounds and *qi* into sixty-four hexagrams, belonging to the Metal Virtue of the Autumn Office, the luminous essence of the *po*. The Western Dipper records names under the governance of the White Emperor. Within the human body, it serves as the Attendant of the *po*, presiding over the *po* of the lungs, the Flowery Canopy, and the Earthly Root.

The celestial demon of the West is named Fanshan Liumu, subject to the *Yisheng* military arts. On *jiazi* and *yichou* days, the *nayin* corresponds to Metal. One should practice the Western *qi* talisman and concurrently employ the Central Ultimate *qi* method. On other days when the *nayin* pertains to Metal, follow this method.

When inscribing this talisman, face west, press the thumb against the middle joint of the middle finger, grasp the brush with the right hand, and recite the sixty-four characters of the Western Eight Heavens’ sound-text. Visualize the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the West suspended above the clouds, lowering a jewel like a pellet. Strike the teeth three times, draw a mouthful of white *qi* from the jewel, and blow it onto the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"By the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning, Fanshan Liumu, Demon King, receives the Great Law of Yisheng. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute!"*

Next, inscribe the talisman: first write *Fanshan Liumu*, then trace the eight trigrams. Write the character *chi* (敕), turn the brush seven times, and lift it as prescribed.

**Great Demon-Subduing Talisman of the Black Emperor**
Light incense, sit calmly, face north, and regulate the breath for over ten cycles until even and prolonged. Imagine black *qi* dispersing from the ears, the sound within resembling the faint chirping of cicadas, lingering intermittently. Naturally, the spirit and *qi* become tranquil, and the Blood Monarch pays homage to the Origin.

For all ailments of the limbs, bones, and blood, this method is essential for their dissolution. Next, regulate the breath and hold the *qi*, visualizing the images of the sun and moon in the heavens descending before the brows, illuminating the ten directions. Then, let the sun enter through the left nostril and the moon through the right, proceeding to the back of the crown. Next, let them enter the *dantian*, their radiance shining through the entire body. First, visualize the solar orb within the *dantian*, circulating and revolving nine times. Then, imagine the sun to the left and the moon to the right within the *dantian*, unmoving, emitting five-colored light that ascends through the *Tianzhu* (Heavenly Pillar) to the back of the crown, illuminating the ten directions. Visualize the sun and moon within the *dantian* as if smelting metal and stone in a great furnace. Refine thus at will until cessation. This is the method of the Inner Golden Elixir; with years of practice, one becomes an immortal. If one swirls the *qi* and rinses the mouth, it forms the appearance of flowing pearls.

According to the *Hidden Writ of the North*, from *Juewu Ziyu* to *Youji Duren*, these represent the eight heavens and eight trigrams of the North, sixty-four characters dividing yin and yang into sixty-four hexagrams. Above, they correspond to the Water Virtue of the Winter Office; the essence of *Quyu* (Curved Nurturance); the descent of the Northern Dipper into death; and the governance of the Black Emperor. Within the human body, they pertain to the *Tongxue Jun* (Blood Monarch), presiding over the true yang and the root-generating blood of the kidneys. The celestial demon of the North is named *Jianchou Langfu*, governed by the Black *Sha* (Killing) martial arts. On *Bingzi* and *Dingchou* days, when the *nayin* (sound of the cyclical signs) belongs to Water, perform the *qi* talismans of the North and concurrently those of the *Zhongji* (Central Ultimate). All days when the *nayin* belongs to Water follow this rule.

When inscribing the talisman, face north. With the left hand, press the second joint of the middle finger; with the right hand, hold the brush. Recite the sixty-four characters of the *Yinwen* (Sound Text) of the Eight Heavens of the North. Close your eyes and visualize the Eight Heavenly Emperor Lords of the North upon the clouds, suspending a jewel as large as a pellet. Strike the teeth three times, draw the black *qi* from the jewel, and blow it onto the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"By the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning, Demon King Jianchou Langfu, receive the Great Law of the Black Sha. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute!"*

Next, inscribe the talisman: first write *Jianchou Langfu*, then trace the eight trigrams, then write the character *chi* (敕). Turn the brush seven times and lift it as prescribed.

**Great Demon-Subduing Talisman of the Yellow Emperor**
Light incense, sit calmly, and regulate the breath for over ten cycles until even and prolonged. Visualize black *qi* at the crown of the head ascending into the azure heavens, transforming into a palace with a defined circular form. Imagine yourself clad in a robe of five-colored clouds and mist, wearing a crown adorned with *liu* (pendant strings of beads), holding a jade tablet, and seated in bejeweled slippers. Within the circular form you perceive, a numinous light illuminates the space between heaven and earth, resembling the celestial palace where the Heavenly Emperor resides, all naturally manifesting. This is used to summon the Lord of the Central Yellow Emperor.

This is the method of the *Zhongji* (Central Ultimate) of the Primordial Beginning, governed by the Great *Kui* Lord of the Central Dipper. As the scripture states: *"The Central Yellow Emperor, unrivaled by the myriad spirits, oversees the offices of all numinous beings."* The demon king is named *Hengtian Danli*. This revered one resides above the Four Ultimates, the essence of the Earth Virtue of the Primordial Upright *qi*. The method of cultivating the circular image of perfection gathers *qi* into the realm of the formless. After practicing this, one returns to the root and restores life, refining essence to nourish *qi*, refining *qi* to nourish spirit, and refining substance to attain perfection. As the scripture states: *"Ascend to the Upper Clarity, enter and exit the Flowery Chambers; within the Eight Obscurities and the subtlest realms, below it governs the human body, the *Niuwan* (Mud Pill Palace) and *Jianggong* (Crimson Palace); centrally, it harmonizes the five *qi* and unites the hundred spirits. With ten revolutions, the spirit returns; with the myriad *qi*, one ascends as an immortal."*

On *Gengwu* and *Xinwei* days, when the *nayin* belongs to Earth, perform the *qi* talismans of the *Zhongji* (Central Ultimate) exclusively, without combining the methods of the four directions. All days when the *nayin* belongs to Earth follow this rule, ensuring the completion of both the Inner and Outer Golden Elixirs.

When inscribing this talisman, face east and visualize the center. With the left hand, palm upward, press the middle joint of the middle finger and hold the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"Radiance establishes completion and deliverance; life repels and disperses to achieve perfection."*

Visualize the Primordial Beginning Supreme Emperor in the layered heavens, suspending a jewel from which five-colored *qi* emanates. Inhale the *qi* and blow it onto the brush. Recite the incantation:

*"By the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning, Demon King Hengtian Danli, receive the Great Law of the Central Dipper’s Great Kui. Enable me to refine essence to nourish *qi*, refine *qi* to nourish spirit, refine substance to attain perfection, and ascend this very day. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute!"*

Next, use cinnabar to inscribe the talisman: first write *Hengtian Danli*, omitting the trigrams. Then write the ten characters *Guangming Lichengdu Shengpi Rangducheng* (光明立成度生辟禳度成). Next, write the character *chi* (敕), turn the brush once, and lift it as prescribed.

This method is the Way of the Supreme Perfected, enabling one to ascend to the Golden Gates and wander in the Jade Capital. When adepts of the Dao practice to this point, they swallow and ingest according to the previous method.

The above five talismans, when used to aid others and treat illness, should be matched to the corresponding viscera based on the Five Phases. For example, if the illness is in the liver, use the talisman of the East. For disasters such as water, fire, or weapons, use the talisman of the phase that overcomes them. If the calamity is water, use the talisman of the Central Earth to remedy it.

When inscribing talismans on objects, instruments, or implements, whether in grass script or seal script, they may vary in size, but the sounds, texts, principles, and strokes must not be lost for efficacy.

The Master said: *"Since the Crimson Clarity opened the chart, and Shennong, the Flame Emperor, the thirty-two Heavenly Emperor Lords descended in succession to the world, establishing the Way of purity and correctness. In the time of the Yellow Emperor of Youxiong, the thirty-two Heavenly Emperor Lords began anew. Selecting the clear and turbid, they established the images of the methods, all pertaining to the Way of form and substance. The Heavenly Perfected recorded their texts as the orthodoxy of the Five Phases. From antiquity, the images of the Five Phases and trigrams have been employed as the Way of long life and aiding beings. The Numinous Writ of the Thirty-Two Heavens is the office through which the Supreme Emperor governs, corresponding below to the honored titles of emperors and kings."*

Since antiquity following the Yellow Emperor’s cultivation of perfection and ascent to the Great August Yellow Once-Heaven, through the cyclic succession of a hundred kings down to the Tang’s Illustrious Emperor Xuanzong, who ascended to the Heaven of Primordial Potency, all have been recorded in canonical texts. The lords of Zhou Mu, Qin Shi, and Han Wu, along with their attendant ministers, may also be enumerated and examined. Thus we know that the Way by which heaven-men and superior scholars ascend to perfection lies concealed within esoteric writings. Within the Thirty-Two Heavens, each heaven contains eight sonic characters, and one celestial pole comprises sixty-four sonic characters in total, establishing the images of the Eight Trigrams. Those who obtain them may attain long life. For the celestial script is the script of sun, moon, stars, and earth, the script of mountains, rivers, forests, and humankind. The essence, qi, and spirit of sun, moon, and stars employ luminous radiance through the Dao; the mountains, rivers, and forests employ the measure of life through the Dao. Thus the scripture states: “Without script, there is no illumination; without script, there is no clarity; without script, there is no establishment; without script, there is no completion; without script, there is no deliverance; without script, there is no life.” It further states: “Nothing is not opened, nothing is not exorcised, nothing is not delivered, nothing is not completed.” Such is the wondrous efficacy of the Dao.

Therefore, the Thirty-Two Heavens descend to govern the human body, extending to the four limbs, nine orifices, five viscera, and six bowels, mysteriously aligning with the thirty-two celestial palaces. Those who know and cultivate this align with the Dao of Heaven. Moreover, there is the Yellow Emperor’s True Round Image Great Method of cultivation, which follows the Five Phases and five qi, prescribing the daily ingestion of a qi talisman corresponding to each direction—all essential techniques of governance.

In the time of the Yellow Emperor, when he was harmed by demonic forces, he employed the talismanic charts of the Five Directions, inscribing them upon swords and halberds to subdue and annihilate them. He also painted images upon the banners of the Five Directions to battle Chiyou at Zhuolu. Thus we know that the Round Image can stir and move the Round Ultimate. Later, when his merit was fulfilled and virtue perfected, he ascended in broad daylight. The Yellow Emperor’s writings state: “The correctness of the Dipper’s Wilds corresponds to the Round Image’s earth.” After its location was lost, only Emperor Xuanzong diligently sought it, learning that a divine person had presented it upon the Huai River, where the four directions aligned in perfect square. There he established the Hall of the Dipper’s Wilds, now ruined and reduced to pavilions.

In ancient times, when Yu the Great controlled the floods, he observed the script of the Great Brahmā’s numinous sound and Eight Trigrams, following the configurations of mountains and rivers to bore springs and excavate caverns. Moving with flying steps through the Round Image, he dredged and cleared the Nine Rivers—all through divine efficacy—thus achieving the governance of Great Peace. The lords of Zhou Mu, Qin Shi, and Han Wu all sought this Way, yet most lost its source. Later generations altered the Round Image talismanic charts, adding or omitting strokes based on Yu’s regulation of the Five Phases’ configurations, rendering them devoid of sonic resonance.

By the Eastern Jin, the Perfected One Xu Xun, harmed by demonic forces in the rivers and lakes, personally received the Yellow Emperor’s writings and inscribed the Five Talismans upon iron tablets, casting them into the Xiang shallows to sever and vanquish demonic toxins. These talismanic tablets remain beneath the Bright Pool of Changsha. The Perfected One employed them to govern demonic forces, save living beings, accumulate merit and cultivate conduct, and ultimately ascend with his entire household. The Immortal Elder Ge Hong often used these talismans, inscribing them upon water on days when the Five Phases mutually overcame one another, causing the script to flow upstream—all who witnessed it recognized its divine marvel.

During the Qin Emperor’s search for numinous traces, his minister Xu Fu presented the *Yu’s Steps Celestial and Terrestrial Round Image* and the *Book of Subduing Demons*. He desired to make the people pure and correct, urging them to wear and practice it, enabling them to journey to the Azure Vaults by morning and return to the imperial palace by evening. Yet he abandoned Confucian studies, yearned for the dwelling of Penglai, and conscripted the people, causing countless unjust deaths. Losing proper governance, he forfeited his mandate as an official of the Heavenly Emperor. Thus we know that the sage-kings of antiquity and the rulers of today all correspond to the governance of the Thirty-Two Heavens.

In the *Xuanhe* era’s *gengzi* cycle, its image was square within and round without; in the *bingwu* year, its image was round within and square without. Thus the northwest suffered floods and the scourge of warfare. Knowing this, one should establish the Round Image to correspond with the Huai River, inscribe the numinous talismans and cast them upon the Three Mountains to govern this cyclical conjunction. Thus may Heaven be preserved in perpetuity, the myriad people rely upon it, and the living and dead obtain blessings.

Herein is briefly recorded its marvels, serving as essential and verified scripture.

*Concluding the Twentieth Scroll of the* Great Method of the Numinous Treasure’s Immeasurable *Sutra of Salvation for Humanity*
*Beginning the Twenty-First Scroll of the* Great Method of the Numinous Treasure’s Immeasurable *Sutra of Salvation for Humanity*

**The True Forms of the Five Peaks**

In ancient times, Emperor Wu of Han, fond of the Dao of longevity, frequently offered sacrifices to renowned mountains and great marshes, praying to the numinous peaks in quest of divine transcendents’ response. In the first month of the *yuanfeng* reign’s first year, on the *jiazi* day, he ascended Mount Songgao, erected a Daoist palace, and fasted for seven days. Upon completing the rites, he returned.

By the fourth month, on the *wuchen* day, while in quiet repose with Dongfang Shuo and Dong Zhongshu at his side, he suddenly beheld a woman clad in azure robes, of extraordinary beauty. Startled, the Emperor asked who she was. She replied, “I am the Jade Maiden of the Walled City Palace, sent by the Queen Mother of the West from Mount Kunlun to speak with you. I hear you wish to relinquish the emoluments of the Four Seas, seek the Dao, and transcend the throne of kingship, yet you repeatedly pray to the sacred peaks—how earnest is your heart! The Way of transcendence may be taught. Fast for a hundred days, abstain from worldly affairs, and on the seventh day of the seventh month, the Queen Mother of the West shall briefly descend.”

Emperor Wu descended from his seat and knelt in assent. The maiden vanished without a trace.

Thereupon, the Emperor ascended the Terrace of Seeking the True, fasting in stillness to cultivate the Dao, while entrusting governance to his ministers. By the seventh day of the seventh month, he purified the inner palace, arranged a seat in the great hall, spread brocade upon the ground, burned incense of a hundred harmonies, hung cloud-patterned silk curtains, lit nine luminous lamps, and prepared grape wine and sweet nectar as offerings for host and guest. Clad in ceremonial robes, he stood at the foot of the steps, commanding that none within the palace gates dare peer forth. Within and without, all was hushed and still, awaiting the arrival of the immortal officials.

After the second watch of the night, a white cloud suddenly arose in the southwest, dense and swift, advancing directly toward the palace. Soon, the sounds of flutes, drums, and the clamor of men and horses filled the air. After half a meal’s time, the Queen Mother arrived before the Suspended-Head Hall, as if birds alighting. Some rode cloud-dragons and cloud-tigers, some white deer, some white *lin* beasts, some white cranes; others came in chariots or astride celestial steeds. Thousands of transcendents filled the courtyard.

Once they arrived, their attendants vanished from sight. Only the Queen Mother was visible, seated in a carriage of purple clouds, drawn by nine multicolored striped dragons. Fifty celestial transcendents flanked her cloud-chariot, each a *zhang* in height, bearing soft-tasseled staffs, girded with golden celestial seals, wielding the staves of perfected beings, and leaning against the pillars below the hall. The Queen Mother, supported by two attendants, ascended the hall. The attendants appeared sixteen or seventeen years of age, clad in azure-sashed cassia robes, their gazes distant and spirits luminous.

The Queen Mother took her seat facing east, draped in a yellow brocade robe, its patterns radiant, golden light shimmering. A great sash of cloud-patterned silk crossed her chest, and at her waist hung the Sword of Divided Radiance. Upon her head rested the knot of Mount Taihua, crowned with the Diadem of Supreme Darkness and Dawn. Her feet were shod in black jade phoenix-embroidered slippers. Her brilliance illuminated the cloud-adorned beams, her divine radiance resplendent. Though she appeared but thirty years of age, her stature was perfect, her celestial grace profound, her cloud-like visage peerless—a true daughter of heaven.

Descending from her carriage and ascending the dais, Emperor Wu bowed and knelt, exchanging courtesies. Then, as if by prior arrangement, he was summoned to sit beside her. The Emperor faced south, while the Queen Mother personally prepared the feast, its refinement unparalleled. Rare delicacies, fragrant fruits, purple mushrooms, jade elixirs, and powders filled the platters. The clear, sweet nectar, unlike anything of the mortal realm, bore a fragrance so exquisite the Emperor could not name it.

She then commanded her attendants to fetch peaches. Soon, a jade platter bore seven peaches, each the size of a goose egg, round and verdant. The Queen Mother presented them to the Emperor, who received four, while she consumed three. The peaches were so sweet and savory that their flavor lingered in the mouth. The Emperor saved the pits, and the Queen Mother asked why. He replied, “I wish to plant them.” She said, “These peaches bear fruit but once in three thousand years. The soil of the mortal realm is too meager—they will not grow.” The Emperor desisted.

He then prostrated himself and confessed: “I, Liu Che, unworthy and untalented, have wallowed in the mundane world. Inheriting the legacy of my ancestors, I am shackled by worldly burdens. My governance is flawed, the people ignorant; the seasons are disordered, the Five Grains barren. My virtue and grace do not extend far, and bandits and foreign foes assail me. I am unfit to be their lord, my sins as towering as mountains. Yet from youth, I have cherished the Dao of longevity and admired the divine transcendents. I have not been able to abandon rank and renown to dwell in the mountains and forests, to sever worldly ties and know not where to turn. Forsaking the world to seek the True, I have drilled and inquired without a teacher. Time presses upon me, and I fear my years will swiftly pass. Never did I imagine that celestial transcendents would suddenly descend. Today, this humble servant is fortunate to behold Your Sagely Eminence. It must be my destined fate to attain deliverance. I beseech you, take pity and grant me the teachings I have yet to comprehend, that I may receive and uphold your profound instructions.”

The Queen Mother replied: “That you scorn glory and delight in humility, immersing yourself in the savor of the Dao, is already commendable. Yet your passions and desires are excessive, your licentiousness and disorder extreme. Your killing and punitive measures are unlawful, your extravagance innate. Lust is the chariot that rends the body, licentiousness the axe that shatters the years. Killing invites retribution, extravagance rots the heart. Desires accumulate and the spirit perishes; filth gathers and life is severed. With a body so slight, you harbor the thieves of annihilation; with timber a foot long, you invite a hundred blades. How can you hope to escape the three-foot noose and preserve your body forever? It is like a wingless bird longing to soar over the celestial pond, or a morning mushroom yearning for spring and autumn.

If you can sweep away these manifold disorders, purge impurity and transform your nature, preserve your spirit and *qi* within the Crimson Palace, seal the Palace of Lust and never open it, still extravagance in the chamber of stillness, cherish all living beings without endangering them, uphold these precepts of the Dao, contemplate the savor of the numinous, practice benevolence and bestow benefits, refine your essence and treasure your *qi*, dispel frivolity, and hasten the departure of all competitions—if you conduct yourself thus, shall you not attain something akin to the Way?”

Should you fail to do so, it would be as futile as embracing a stone to cross a vast river.

The Emperor knelt to receive the sacred precepts and pledged to heed these words. He then noticed a small scroll in the Queen Mother’s sash, encased in a purple brocade pouch. The Emperor inquired whether this scroll was a divine formula, and whether he might dare to gaze upon it. The Queen Mother brought it forth, saying, “This is the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*. The immortals of Mount Qingcheng recently sought it from me, and I shall soon pass it to them. It was issued by the Supreme Lord of the Three Heavens, its scriptures secret and its prohibitions weighty—how could your impure frame be worthy to bear it? For now, I shall give you the *Scripture of Numinous Radiance and Vital Flourishing*, which may open your spirit and inspire your resolve.”

The Emperor persisted in his entreaty. The Queen Mother replied, “In the first year of the *Pure Numinosity* reign of the Supreme August One, the Supreme Lord of the Dao, the Heavenly Honored One, descended to survey the Six Directions. He measured the length of the Milky Way, assessed the heights of mountains and depths of valleys, named the lofty pillars to stabilize the earth’s principles, and established the Five Peaks as anchors for the realm’s guardians. He honored Mount Kunlun as the abode of divine immortals, exalted Mount Penglai as the retreat of perfected beings, stationed the water spirits at the source of utmost yin, and settled the Great Emperor in the ruins of Fusang. Thus, Mount Fangzhang became the chamber of destiny’s governance, while the isles of the Canglang Sea housed the halls of the Nine Elders. The lands of Zuying, Xuan’yan, and Changyuan, where the streams of life flow endlessly, and the caverns where phoenixes and unicorns gather, each bore the names of their respective isles—all lying amidst the dark currents of the vast ocean. Its waters were jade-black, their waves surging and crashing. Divine immortals, jade maidens, and hosts of spirits dwelled within the azure sea. Though their names were elusive, their forms were distinct.

You observe the contours of mountains, the winding paths of rivers and peaks, the undulations of ridges and mounds, the towering heights and sweeping lengths of ranges, their spiraling, serpentine forms resembling written characters. Thus, their names were fashioned according to their shapes, their titles fixed to reflect their essence. Their images were inscribed upon the Dark Terrace and issued as tokens of the numinous and true. When immortals bear them, it is as if they carry transmitted seals. When Daoists hold them and traverse mountains and rivers, the hundred spirits and lords of the numinous pay them homage and welcome them with reverence.

Though you are not yet perfected, your repeated journeys to mountains and marshes, your earnest quest for the Dao, have not been forgotten. Delighted by your sincerity, I now bestow this upon you. You must treasure it deeply, as you would serve a sovereign or father. Should you reveal it to the unworthy, calamity will surely follow.

According to the statutes of the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital and the *Luminous Mandate of the Nine Qi Venerable*, the *Great Numinous Writings* were all composed by the Supreme Lord of the Dao, the Heavenly Honored One of the Three Heavens. Some were crafted by the Heavenly Perfected of the Three Sovereigns, others issued by the Red Youths, the True Persons and Divine Parents of the Nine Heavens. Such texts are transmitted to but one person every thirty years. If no worthy recipient is found in forty years, the transmission is withheld; in eighty years, only two may receive it. To confer it upon the unworthy is to leak the Way of Heaven. To withhold it from the deserving is to hoard Heaven’s treasure. To bestow it recklessly without regard for limits is to trifle with Heaven’s elders. To receive it without reverence is to scorn Heaven’s splendor. Leaking, hoarding, trifling, and scorning—these four transgressions summon the chariots of retribution. Leaking brings death upon the road, the recipient’s form vanishing and their bones scattering. Hoarding brings blindness and deafness in future lives, their vitality withering in sudden demise. Trifling brings misfortune upon one’s parents, consigning them to Fengdu for punishment. Scorning brings a violent end, followed by affliction with grievous illness in the next life. Worse still are those whose crimes sever their lineage and annihilate their clan.

Those of the same Dao are called Heaven’s kin; those of the same heart are called Earth’s beloved. In transmission, there must be mutual affection, shared honor and disgrace, a united heart in truth, and cherished essence and fluid. Together, you must cultivate harmonious *qi*; when *qi* is whole, spirit returns, and you shall surely attain the assembly of the numinous. Should you fail in this, Heaven will visit calamity upon you. These are the statutes and prohibitions of the Dao, warnings passed down through the ages—you must not be careless.

If you seek someone to whom you might transmit this, Dong Zhongjun appears to be a fitting candidate.” She then commanded her attendants to retrieve another scroll, which she presented to Emperor Wu. The attendant drew from her bosom a scroll of sacred writ, its brilliance equal to the first. The Queen Mother placed it in the Emperor’s hands, and he knelt to receive it with reverence.

The Queen Mother said, “Should you succeed in clarifying your true nature, turning from evil and cultivating goodness, return in three years and seven months, and I shall reveal more of the Dao to you.”

Suddenly, from the southern window of the vermilion bird hall, a figure peered in at the Queen Mother. The Emperor, startled, asked who it was. The Queen Mother replied, “You do not recognize him? He is your attendant, Dongfang Shuo. A mischievous boy from my neighborhood, he has thrice stolen these peaches. Formerly an immortal official of Mount Tai, the Supreme Lord sent him to Fangzhang to assist the Celestial Controller of Destinies in examining the households of immortals. Yet upon arriving at Fangzhang, he indulged only in wandering mountains and waters, neglecting to cultivate harmonious *qi*. He wantonly manipulated thunder and lightning, stirred waves and scattered sand, disrupting the timely rhythms of wind and rain, throwing yin and yang into disorder. This caused dragons and leviathans to crawl on land, mountains to crumble, borders to collapse, the sea to dry up violently, and the Yellow River to overflow unpredictably. He harmed the fields of grain and magic mushrooms, drowned himself in wine, and failed in his duties of harmonious governance, violating the statutes of his commission. The Venerable of the Nine Springs reported this to the Supreme Lord, who demoted and banished him to the mortal realm, exiling him from the court of the Great Clarity to dwell among the foul and stinking masses.

Nine years ago, two immortals from Mount Huangjinhua and the Lord of Mount Jiuyi petitioned on his behalf. Only then did I learn that Shuo was no ordinary man.” She then recounted to Emperor Wu the names of the immortal officials in her retinue, their attire, and the names of the objects they bore, explaining how they had attained their ranks.

As evening approached, the Queen Mother took her leave. Her procession of dragons and tigers, with drums and flutes leading the way, mirrored her arrival. Clouds billowed thickly, suffused with fragrance, and as she vanished into the southwest, the scent lingered long after.

Having witnessed the Queen Mother, the Emperor came to believe in the existence of divine immortals and began to contemplate plans for transcending the world. Yet he remained enslaved to lust and ceaseless in warfare, burdening the people with labor and filling the innocent with resentment. He disregarded the Queen Mother’s words, and she never returned.

The late Queen Mother, when she met the Emperor, spoke at length of many things—methods for extending life, arts for summoning spirits. The Emperor compiled these into a scroll, along with the scriptures and diagrams she had bestowed upon him. He placed them upon a table of yellow gold, sealed them in a casket of white jade, and stored them atop the Cypress-Beam Terrace.

Later, in the first year of the *Taichu* era, heavenly fire consumed the terrace. Thus were the *True Forms*, the *Scripture of Numinous Radiance*, and the Emperor’s own compilation of essential teachings lost to the flames. The Queen Mother, seeing that the Emperor had ignored her instructions, brought this calamity upon him.

Yet earlier, the Emperor had heeded the Queen Mother’s words and entrusted the diagrams to Dong Zhongjun. Zhongjun made a copy, and by this means they were preserved.

One day thereafter, Dongfang Shuo mounted a cloud-dragon and soared away. The assembled crowd saw him ascend from the northwest, rising gently into the heavens. As they gazed upward, a great mist enveloped him, and he vanished from sight. The Emperor was filled with remorse, knowing he had lost the Way.

That year, in the twelfth month, he performed the *tan* and *hao* rites in the Local Shrine, sacrificing to the Earth Queen. He journeyed east to the Bohai Sea to offer prayers to Mount Penglai. In spring, he returned to Ganyuan to receive the annual accounts. In the second month, he began construction of the Jianzhang Palace. In summer, the fifth month, he reformed the calendar, making the first month the beginning of the year, adopting yellow as the auspicious color, and using five as the standard number. He standardized official titles, harmonized musical tones, and dispatched General Gongsun Ao to build the Outer Wall’s Surrender-Accepting Fortress. In autumn, the eighth month, he traveled to Anding and sent General Li Guangli, the Ershi General, to mobilize exiled convicts from across the realm for a western campaign against Dayuan.

He revised the calendar to begin the year in the first month—this was the Queen Mother’s intent. Reflecting upon the Queen Mother, the matriarch of all immortals, one must treasure these texts. How much more should ordinary, petty men revere them?

When Emperor Wu asked Dongfang Shuo about the Queen Mother’s words, Shuo’s response was as recorded elsewhere.

Master Green Ox said: "My family possesses the *True Forms of the Five Peaks*. Each peak dispatches five spirits to guard and protect the diagrams and scriptures. For those who dwell in the mountains, the mountain and marsh spirits also constantly send officials to defend their bodies and households. If wicked men seek to harm them, the harm rebounds upon themselves. These forms repel the five weapons and the five pestilences; one may tread upon blades unscathed. They also expose human deceit and perversity—those who act unjustly bring misfortune upon themselves, while the impure bring calamity upon their households. Thus, one must be deeply cautious and reverent.

Whoever carries these texts or holds them while traversing mountains and forests will be met with bows and reverence from the hundred mountains’ earthly spirits and numinous lords. Even ghosts and spirits abase themselves in obeisance—how much more should ordinary men refrain from negligence?

The rivers and mountains—Jiang, He, Huai, and the central ranges—all fall under the governance of the Central Peak’s domain. Those who enter the mountains to gather the eight stones—stone likenesses, stone brains, flowing cinnabar, flowing pearls, flying stalks, yellow seeds, stone marrow, cassia blossoms, and divine herbs—will never obtain these immortal treasures without wearing the *Five Peaks Diagram*.

The proper method for wearing it is this: wrap it in blue silk, or use white silk, and place it in a purple pouch. One may wear it upon the head or bind it to the heart or elbow. No mountain, great or small, lacks its spirit. When the spirit appears, it will declare, ‘I am So-and-So of Such-and-Such Mountain, come to welcome you.’ The Most High True Person has designated these bamboo tally texts of the Five Peaks to guard this diagram and scripture. Just as people today respect the insignia and staffs of provincial inspectors, so too do the mountain spirits come to pay homage.

The method of transmission is restricted: it may be passed on only once every forty years, with a blood oath as covenant. Whoever keeps this text in their home will have the Five Peaks each dispatch five spirits to safeguard the diagram. The spirits of the mountains, rivers, sources, and marshes where they dwell will each send attendants to protect their person. If others harbor malice, plot against them, slander them, or seek to harm them—even if the authorities arrest them—the twenty-five spirits guarding the Five Peaks, along with the mountain and river attendants, will report to the lord of their resident peak. The spirits will then turn the harm back upon those who wished it, causing it to rebound upon themselves.

Those who receive this must not fail to purify their bodies and minds. If they act with perversity, negligence, or disrespect—if they slight the sacred trust or treat the teachings with contempt—disaster will strike, and their households will be destroyed. They must not be careless.

Entering the mountains without the *True Forms* invites corruption by myriad spirits. Gathering herbs without them invites obstruction by the mountain’s numina. Pursuing the Dao without them leaves the hun and qi unsettled, and the Three Corpses will sow chaos. Of a thousand paths and ten thousand affairs, none can be accomplished without this text. But with it worn upon the body, one may harmonize the household spirits, traverse heaven and earth unobstructed, be guarded by divine beings at home, and be welcomed by mountain spirits when abroad. Gathering and consuming divine herbs, one will be protected by true immortals. Passing through plagues and perils, heavenly disasters will vanish of their own accord. Thus may one depart in emptiness and return in fullness, with the truth of fortune and misfortune made manifest. Those of the Dao who come after must keep it secret and hold it in reverence."

In the first year of the *Yuanfeng* era, the Queen Mother of the West bestowed upon Emperor Xiaowu the *Preface to the Diagram of the Five Peaks*.

The *True Forms of the Five Peaks* as transmitted by Dongfang Shuo are representations of mountains and waters. The twisting boulders, the contours of hills and mounds, their heights and depths, lengths and folds—waves surge beneath the flourishing brush, peaks and ridges sharpen in clarity. Clouds and forests, dark and yellow, take on the appearance of written characters. Thus did the Heavenly Perfected Lord of the Dao descend to observe their patterns, tracing their paths and tendencies. Following the rhythm of the characters, he named the mountains according to their forms.

Whoever possesses the form of the Eastern Peak will enjoy peace of spirit and extension of life, preserving their body for long ages. Entering mountains and crossing rivers, a hundred divine herbs will gather of their own accord.

Whoever possesses the form of the Southern Peak will be untouched by the five pestilences, repelling fire and light. Those who plot evil against them will suffer harm in return.

Whoever possesses the form of the Central Peak will find all their pursuits profitable, amassing vast wealth. If they seek to forge alliances, it will require no labor of body or strength.

Whoever possesses the form of the Western Peak will dispel the weapons of kings, walk unharmed through blades, and be revered and welcomed by the spirits of mountains and rivers.

Whoever possesses the form of the Northern Peak will be spared disaster when entering water, with all poisons subdued. They will command dragons and enjoy enduring blessings and fortune.

If you possess the forms of all Five Peaks, you shall traverse heaven and earth, encompassing the four directions. When the spirits behold you with joy, humans and gods alike will be of one accord.

In ancient times, the Yellow Emperor mustered the lords for battle against Chiyou in the wilds of Zhuolu. Having captured the rebellious lords, all revered Xuanyuan as the Son of Heaven, succeeding Shennong as the Yellow Emperor. Whenever there were those in the realm who refused to submit, he would lead expeditions to subdue them. He shattered mountains to open roads, never resting in one place. To the east, he reached the sea, ascending Mount Tai to inscribe the Dai Zong. To the west, he arrived at Kongtong, climbing Jitou. To the south, he came to the Jiang, ascending Xiongxiang. To the north, he pressed on to Hui Zhou, uniting the talismans at Fushan, and established his capital in the wilds of Zhuolu. His movements were ceaseless, without fixed abode.

Observing that the Four Peaks each had auxiliary mountains of destiny, only the Southern Peak stood solitary without support. Thus, he composed a petition to the Three Heavens’ Supreme Dao Lord, designating Mount Huo and Mount Qian as reserve lords. The petition was approved. The Emperor then personally crafted the mountains, inscribing their forms and images, linking them to the Five Peaks. He further commanded Qingcheng as the Abode of the Venerable Elder and Mount Lu as the Form of the Envoy, arranging them in proper sequence to continue this legacy, which began with the Yellow Emperor.

The Lord of the Eastern Peak, Mount Tai, commands a host of five thousand nine hundred officials. He governs plagues and the cycle of life and death, serving as the marshal of all ghosts. He is the ancestral lord of blood sacrifices and temple rites. All those who die worshipping heretical spirits or malevolent deities in the mundane world are sent to Mount Tai to receive punishment and judgment. When those who bear the forms of the Five Peaks enter the mountains and forests or visit Mount Tai, the Lord of Mount Tai and the spirits of all mountains and rivers will come forth to welcome and bow to them. The Lord of Mount Tai wears a cyan robe, a seven-tiered azure crown, and bears the Seal of Pervading Yang and Great Brilliance. He rides a green dragon, accompanied by his retinue, to welcome you.

The Lord of the Southern Peak, Mount Heng, commands seventy thousand seven hundred immortals. When you enter the mountains under his jurisdiction, all mountain spirits will come forth to welcome you. The Lord of the Southern Peak wears a robe of vermilion radiance, a crown of Ninefold Cinnabar and Solar Essence, and bears the Seal of Night Radiance and Supreme Perfection. He rides a red dragon, accompanied by his retinue, to welcome you.

The Lord of the Central Peak, Mount Song, commands thirty thousand jade maidens. When you enter the mountains under his domain, all renowned spirits of the Central Peak will come forth to welcome you. The Lord of the Central Peak wears a robe of yellow silk, a crown of Yellow Jade and Great Si, and bears the Talisman of Divine Harmony and Yang. He rides a yellow dragon, accompanied by his ministers, to welcome you. The Central Peak is the sovereign of the Five Peaks; you should revere it well. The Supreme Lord often appoints True Persons of virtue and renown from the Three Heavens to serve as its lord.

The Lord of the Western Peak, Mount Hua, commands four thousand one hundred immortals and jade maidens. When you traverse the mountains and rivers under his domain, all spirits will come forth to welcome you. The Lord of Mount Hua wears a robe of white silk, a crown of Supreme Simplicity and Nine Streams, and bears the Talisman of Opening Heaven and Communing with the Perfected. He rides a white dragon to welcome you.

The Lord of the Northern Peak, Mount Heng, commands seven thousand immortal youths and jade maidens. When you enter the mountains and rivers under his jurisdiction, all spirits will come forth to welcome you. The Lord of the Northern Peak wears a robe of dark radiance, a crown of Supreme Obscurity and Yin Spirit, and bears the Talisman of Eternal Tranquility and Realization of the Perfected. He rides a black dragon to welcome you.

The Venerable Elder of Qingcheng was appointed by the Yellow Emperor to govern earthbound immortals and serve as the overseer of the Five Peaks, unifying all their ministers. The Venerable Elder commands ten thousand immortal officials. When Daoists enter his peak, the Venerable Elder wears a robe of vermilion radiance, a canopy-like crown, and bears the Seal of the Three Courts. He rides a carriage drawn by auspicious beasts, accompanied by a host of spirits, to welcome you.

The Envoy of Mount Lu was appointed by the Yellow Emperor, holding a rank comparable to the Imperial Censor. He oversees the taboos of all immortal officials, serving as the inspector of the Five Peaks. When Daoists enter his mountain, the Envoy wears a robe of vermilion elegance, a crown of level splendor, and bears the Talisman of the True Forms of the Three Heavens. He also rides a carriage drawn by auspicious beasts to welcome you.

The Reserve Lord of the Southern Peak, Mount Huo, was appointed by the Yellow Emperor as the deputy of Mount Heng. He commands thirty thousand spirits. Above, he harmonizes the qi; below, he succors the common people. He governs the water spirits by the decrees of the assembled immortals, serving as the repository of majestic authority and the object of reverence for all spirits. When Daoists enter his domain, the Reserve Lord wears a robe of azure brocade, a crown of Dawning Light, and bears the Jade Staff of the Dao Lord. He comes to welcome you, sometimes riding a carriage or a tiger, without fixed form.

The Reserve Lord of Mount Qian was appointed by the Yellow Emperor as the secondary deputy of Mount Heng, occasionally participating in governance to assist in his duties. When you enter his mountain, the Reserve Lord of Mount Qian wears embroidered robes of purple radiance, a crown of Tri-Star Spirit, and bears the Seal of the Vermilion Palace. He rides a chariot drawn by a red dragon to welcome you.

The Lords of the Auxiliary Mountains all assist the Peak Lords in governance. When Daoists enter their mountains, the Auxiliary Lords wear vermilion robes, crowns of immortal splendor, and bear the True Form Chapters of the Supreme Lord. They come to welcome you, their mounts varying without fixed form.

Dongfang Shuo said that the ancient illustrations of the true forms of the Five Peaks, including their heads and eyes, originated from the pre-Shennong era, derived from the *Eight Assemblies of the Flying Celestials* script of the Supreme Lord—a script predating even the age of bird-track writing. Without the annotations and explanations of immortals, their meanings would remain forever obscure. When Daoists wish to bear these talismans, they should select the mountain’s image and inscribe the ancient script, rolling it up and inscribing the exterior. The talisman should be worn during the first *yin* month, after establishing a seven-day fast. During the fast, the talisman is inscribed, and the offering rites follow the transmission of the method, though the invocations may be adapted to the individual.

Whenever inscribing, incense should be burned beside the image. The *True Form Chart of the Five Peaks of Lingbao* and the *Everlasting Talisman of the Three Heavens’ Supreme Lord*—when Daoists wear these, they may traverse mountains, forests, rivers, and seas, journeying across the world. All spirits will attend and protect them, none daring to obstruct. The rites of fasting, offering, and inscription follow the same name as the Five Peaks. The edict of the Supreme Dao Lord is not to be seen, but it was revealed by Dongfang Shuo.

This predates the traces of birds, resembling the scripts of the Three Sovereigns. Those who wear it should store it together with the *True Form Charts of the Five Peaks*. Only immortals may inscribe the names of mountains and their hidden features with the character "谨" (reverence); no others may do so even once.

By the command of Heaven and Earth, the hills and mounds,
May the gods protect me, the disciple, with care.
Banish harm, grant long-lasting peace,
And preserve wholeness forever.

*Eastern Spring – True Form Chart of the Eastern Peak*
*Southern Summer – True Form Chart of the Southern Peak*
*Central Earth (Wu-Ji Soil) – True Form Chart of the Central Peak*
*Western Autumn – True Form Chart of the Western Peak*
*Northern Winter – True Form Chart of the Northern Peak*
*The Venerable Elder of Mount Qingcheng – True Form Chart of Mount Qingcheng*
*Perfected Lord of Preserving Destiny – True Form Chart of Mount Lu*
*Southern Treasurer of Mount Huo – True Form Chart of Mount Huo*
*Southern Treasurer of Mount Qian – True Form Chart of Mount Qian*

Where ink depicts mountain forms, red marks water sources, and yellow denotes caverns and grottoes. Small depictions indicate subtle features, while large ones signify vast ridges. Height and depth follow the natural contours; length and shape are drawn according to their likeness. At their origins, divine mushrooms and herbs are illustrated. Where chambers are marked, later generations may enter and exit, recognizing and recording these places in the mountains.

*Concluding the Twenty-First Scroll of the Great Method of the Numinous Treasure Sutra of Limitless Salvation*
*Beginning the Twenty-Second Scroll of the Great Method of the Numinous Treasure Sutra of Limitless Salvation*

**Summoning the Divine and Seeking Transcendence**

Whenever one recites the Five True Writings of the Numinous Treasure, visualizes the divine, and invokes the immortals—whatever one seeks—shall be heard by the Nine Heavens, and the Perfected Ones shall come to one’s chamber, granting the body transcendence.

This should be performed on the days of *jiayin* or *yimao* following the Beginning of Spring. Bathe, purify, and fast, then at dawn enter the chamber, face east, and bow nine times. Sit upright, knock the teeth nine times, and awaken the spirits within the body.

Once done, with eyes closed, visualize the Azure Thearch of Mount Tai of the Eastern Marchmount, surnamed *Sui*, whose personal name is [omitted]. His form is nine inches and nine *fen* in height, crowned with a blue jade *tongtian* coronet, clad in a feathered flying robe of azure, and riding a green dragon. He is attended by twelve jade maidens of the green waist, descending into your chamber from the east.

After a while, the Azure Thearch transforms into an infant within a cloud of green *qi*, entering your mouth with the breath and proceeding directly to your abdomen. Visualize a red *qi* arising from the heart, encircling and suffusing the liver. The green and red *qi* intermingle in primordial chaos, like auspicious clouds layered in mist. When you feel warmth suffusing the liver, swallow nine times.

Then raise your head and pray:
*"The Nine Gates of the East—
Within lies the Primordial August One."*

Ascend and descend through the Three Clarities, feasting in the Jade Chamber. Secure and pacify the numinous peaks, dispatching and directing Gou Mang. Above, govern the azure mists, nine thousand ninefold layers. Attend the feathered palanquin, twelve flying dragons in escort. To the left, green-waisted maidens attend; to the right, divine youths guard. They grasp inscribed tablets, jade texts of azure writ. They review and fix the names of immortals, reporting them to the Upper Palace. Today is most auspicious—present your words. Bear the Red Script upon your person, your name recorded in the Emperor’s Hall. May the divine and immortal be inscribed in the Green Register’s ledger. Turn above the numinous chariot to descend into my chamber. The two *qi* intermingle, transforming into an infant’s hazy form. Settle and govern the liver’s palace, summoning radiant splendor. Numinous brilliance flows and pours, bestowing a golden countenance upon the face. Sit in natural attainment, spirits and gods in communion. The body attains longevity, heaven and earth without end.

Conclude by drawing in green *qi* and swallowing nine times, then cease. Practicing this Way for nine years will summon nine green-waisted jade maidens and the numinous officials of Mount Tai in the East to descend, conveying your prayers and wishes upward to the Nine Heavens. For parents in life or death, transgressions recorded and duties assigned to the Eastern Peak—then the gods will erase the names of sins, and you shall attain liberation, ascending to the Hall of Blessings. This method is wondrous and weighty, the bridge between life and death.

Regularly perform this on the days of *bingwu* or *dingwei* after the Beginning of Summer. Bathe and purify, then enter the chamber at noon. Face south, bow three times, sit upright, and knock the teeth three times to awaken the body’s spirits. Conclude, close your eyes, and visualize the Red Thearch of Mount Heng in the South, whose surname is Rong and personal name is [omitted]. His form is three *cun* and three *fen* in height, crowned with a red jade *tongtian* coronet, clad in a feathered flying robe of cinnabar, and riding a crimson dragon. He is attended by twelve jade maidens of the red jasper, descending into your chamber from the south.

After a while, the Red Thearch transforms into a newly born infant within a cloud of red *qi*, entering your mouth with the breath and proceeding directly to your heart. Visualize a yellow *qi* arising from the spleen, encircling and suffusing the heart’s palace. The yellow and red *qi* intermingle in primordial chaos, like the dazzling radiance of blazing fire. When you feel warmth suffusing the heart, swallow three times.

Then raise your head and pray:
*"The Three Lights of the Cinnabar Heavens—
The Jade Gate of the South above.
Within lies the Great Spirit,
The Numinous Lord of the Red Thearch.
Clad in cinnabar, bearing talismanic sashes,
Flying script and feathered skirts.
Riding a crimson dragon,
Descending with the flying clouds.
On the numinous Mount Heng of the South,
Myriad gods hold him in highest honor.
Ascending and descending through the Three Clarities,
Feasting above with the Nine Maidens.
Jade maidens of the red jasper,
